SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. It is quite acceptable to have someone else do the writing at your dictation.

1. Your full name (Mrs.) Helen Marie Mainprize
2. Your address Midale, Sask.
3. Date June 4th 1962
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country).
   Rutland, North Dakota (Sargent County)
5. What was your father's name and occupation?
   Mr. Olaf Wedin - General Merchant.
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year).
   June 2 1908
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.
   Rutland N. Dak.
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child," "I was in my teens," etc.)
   8 years old.
9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   My father came to obtain cheap land and grow crops and get rich in a new country.
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?)
    Through Rev. Olaf Sutherland a real pioneering gent.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. It is quite acceptable to have someone else do the writing at your dictation.

1. Your full name (Mrs.) Helen Marie Mainprize
2. Your address MidaLE, SASK.
3. Date June 4 & 1962
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country) RutLAND North BArKDA (Sargent County)
5. What was your father's name and occupation? Mr. ALAB WEDDIN - GENERAL MERCHANT
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year) June 8, 1908
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible. RutLAND N. Dak.
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child," "I was in my teens," etc.)
9. What were your reasons for coming West? My father came to obtain cheap land and grow crops and get rich in a new country.
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?) Through Rev. O.K. of Sutherland and a rail Pioneering gent.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
   With family

13. What means of transportation did you use?
   By C.P.R. train - Soo Line

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)
   [Handwritten text not legible]

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
   We lived in a tent until fall when the house was ready.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
   Midale, Sask.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
   No other -

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?
   My father had a hardware store and he was a partner in a co-op store that had post office, general merchandising, hardware, and lumber in the new town of Midale, Sask., and they soon became one of us. We all felt like one big family.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

With family

13. What means of transportation did you use?

By C.P.R. train - Soo Line

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

We lived in a tent until fall when the house was ready.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

Mackall, Saskatchewan

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

No other

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?

My father had a hardware store and had two partners in a third store that had he sold a general merchandise hardware store office in the new town of Mitchell, Saskatchewan and they soon became one of us. We all felt like one big family.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

My husband Dr. W.G. Mainprize married Dec 8, 1920 at Midale, Sask.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West, tell when they came and where they settled.

Parents - Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Wedin, brothers Albert and Arthur, sisters Minnie and Pearl.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

After Church on Sunday during the summer, there was a gathering of the whole community at someone's house—often in the country. These were happy times. New settlers would come to these gatherings and they soon became one of us. We all felt like one big family.
3.

19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation as a place to settle?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West, tell when they came and where they settled.

Parents - Mr. and Mrs. Fred Wieden, brothers Alfred and Arthur

Sisters - Minnie and Pearl.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

After church on Sundays during the summer, there was a gathering of us kids Community at xero's house - often in the country. These were happy times. New settlers would come to these gatherings and they soon became one of us. We all felt like one big family.
25. When was the first car used in the community?  
   1910

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?  
   Family car. Hard 1910

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?  
   Midale.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)  
   Yes

29. How often did you shop in the early days?  
   Everyday! at our own store.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?  
   From the early years. There was a settlement some 10 to 15 miles away that came to Midale by wagon and horses always in groups and the store clerks knew the days and were always preparing for them.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.  
   Having a store of our own Eaton's catalogue was taboo but after I was married in 1920 it became a favorite place to shop.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?  
   At home about 1910 or 1911 - Midale Telephone Co. I think.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?  
   My father only planned to stay until his children were ready for a higher education. He passed away in 1906 but his children all went away to school but continued to live in Midale, Sask.
25. When was the first car used in the community? 1910

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?

Family Car Ford 1910

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?

Midale

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)

Yes

29. How often did you shop in the early days?

Everyday at our own store

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?

From the early days there was an adjustment

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogue? What kind of articles did you buy in this way?

Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.

Having a store of our own catalogue

Was taboo but after I was married in 1920 it became a favorite place to shop.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?

At home about 1910 or 1911 - Midale Telephone Co. Ltd.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently?

Or did you make up your mind after trying it out?

My father only planned to stay until his children were ready for a higher education.

My parents moved away in 1906 but his children all moved away to school but continued & his son Midale, Sask.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

very few

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?

A number moved away and some returned. Those who stayed were better off in the end than those who left.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

The man

Brother Albert was Secretary of village for a few years.

We were active in the Baptist Church.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name, (2) origin and meaning of the name, (3) date of its adoption, (4) any changes in names since the first name was given, date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

They named Midale as a tribute to Dr. R.M. Mitchell of Weyburn who took the first two letters Mi and Ole Dale, whose land adjoined the townsite, making the name Midale.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

Very few

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?

A number moved away and some returned.

Those who stayed were better off in the end than those who left.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

Brother Albert was Secretary of village for a few years - we were active in the Baptist Church.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district, mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combining, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name, (2) origin and meaning of the name, (3) date of its adoption, (4) any changes in names since the first name was given, date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

They named Mitchell after Dr. R.M. Mitchell of Weyburn so took the first two letters of his name and added the town site, making the name Mitchell.
39. Questions regarding historical source materials:

Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old posters and programs, minute books of community organizations, old pamphlets, old photographs, written recollections and reminiscences? (Describe.)

Would you or the person who owns them either

(1) be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying?

(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Library, Regina, or the Archives Office at the University in Saskatoon? (Indicate your preference, if any)

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

Our Children: Dr. Graham Mainprize, Central Butte, Sask., grandchild Gary, Lee, and Laura, S. Mrs. Marie McKeown, Cypress, S. Grandson Graham, Bruce, Marybeth, Karen, Paul, Eric.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

The discovery of oil in 1953 brought prosperity to the Community.

Please give the names and addresses of other pioneers who could answer this questionnaire.

Mr. Peter Hultgren, Middle, Sask.
Mrs. Ester Peterson, Middle, Sask.
Mr. Clarence Erickson, Middle, Sask.
